text: Which of the following materials is not a living semi-permeable membrane?
explanation: Semipermeable membrane is a type of biological or synthetic, polymeric membrane that will allow certain molecules or ions to pass through it by osmosis. There are two examples of semi-permeable membrane, which are non-living and living semi-permeable membrane. Examples of non-living semi-permeable membrane which are permeable to water but not solvent e.g copper sulphate solution are visking tube, parchment and cellophane.

text: In an experiment, mould and yeast cells were transferred into an environment with low oxygen concentration. After a few days, the mould dies while the yeast cells did not. Which of the following statements best explains the following observation.

options.A: The yeast cells carried out photosynthesis while the mould did not
options.B: Photosynthesis does not take place in the absence of oxygen
options.C: Respiration can take place in yeast cells in the absence of oxygen
options.D: Respiration does not occur in the mould

text: Which of the following tissues does not provide support in flowering plants?
explanation: The main supporting tissues in plants are parenchyma, collenchyma, sclerenchyma (fibre) and wood (xylem).

text:
The diagram is an illustration of an experimental set-up. Study it and answer the question;
The set-up directly measure

options.A: transpiration of water by the shoot
options.B: evaporation of water from the leaves
options.C: absorption of water by the shoot
options.D: loss of mineral salts from the leaves

text:
The diagram above is an illustration of an experimental setup. Study it and answer the question below;
The setup can measure comparatively the rate of

options.A: evaporation from leaves on a single shoot under different experimental conditions
options.B: salt uptake by shoots from different plants
options.C: transpiration of a single shoot of a plant under different experimental conditions
options.D: water uptake by roots of different plants

explanation: The set-up can measure comparatively the rate of transpiration of a single shoot of a plant under different experimental conditions. Transpiration is the process of water movement through a plant and its evaporation from aerial parts, primarily from the leaves. In the illustration, the plant shoot is enclosed in a container, and the amount of water lost from the shoot is measured. By changing the experimental conditions, such as the temperature or humidity, and measuring the transpiration rate under each set of conditions, the set-up can be used to compare the rates of transpiration under different conditions for a single shoot of a plant.

text: The respiratory organ of a cockroach
The excretory product of some reptiles, birds and insects is
The part of the mammalian kidney that stores urine is the
explanation: The bladder functions as a reservoir and active excretory organ for the urine. Urine excreted by the kidneys passes through the ureters and the ureterovesical junction into the bladder. However, the urine collects in the renal pelvis, which drains into the ureter . Then, the urine moves into the ureter for storage in the urinary bladder. Thus, option D is the best answer.

text: The properties of endocrine system include the following except

options.B: transportation by blood to target organ

text: The part of the central nervous system that controls unconscious actions in humans is the
explanation: The three primary roles of the spinal cord are to send motor commands from the brain to the body, send sensory information from the body to the brain, and coordinate reflexes.

text: What happens when the ciliary muscles of the eye contract? The

options.C: lens gets a longer focal length

explanation: When the ciliary muscles of the eye contract, the lens becomes more convex. This is because the contraction of the ciliary muscles reduces the tension on the suspensory ligaments holding the lens in place, allowing the lens to take on a more rounded (convex) shape. This increases the lens's refractive power, allowing for closer objects to be brought into focus.

text: Replication of DNA molecules is catalysed by an enzyme called
Who proposed the theory of evolution by natural selection
Which of the following statements best explains the reason why termites swarm at night?

options.A: Light is not necessary for swarming
options.D: They can only see in the dark

explanation:
Reasons why termites are most active during the night:
Avoiding Predators:By coming out at night, termites try to avoid their predators like birds, ants, and other insects, who might feed on them during the day. So, this is their self-defense mechanism.
Nesting Behavior:Termites feel more secure during the night. They prefer building new colonies in the ground or inside the woods at night. They feel more secure traveling between their food sources and nests without worrying about being noticed.
Feeding Patterns:Another reason for termites to come out at night is their feeding pattern. These silent destroyers feed on paper, wood, and other organic matter. They prefer emerging out at night in search of food without any disturbance, which is more common and frequent during the daytime.
Colony Organization:Termites usually organize their colonies in different sections like soldiers, workers, and reproductives. Worker termites being more responsible as well as sensitive to the daytime environments,  prefer carrying out their responsibilities during the darkness of night.
Conserving Moisture:Termites can easily dry out and look for ways to conserve moisture to survive. This is not possible during the daytime when the temperature is high, so they come out at night when the air is cooler and humidity levels are higher so that they can conserve moisture for survival.
